title: Erdős #205: Powers of 2 plus numbers with few prime factors

problemStatement.plain: Is it true that all sufficiently large n can be written as 2^k + m with Ω(m) < log log m? (Answer: NO)
whyMatters: Connects covering systems to prime factorization
Related to Romanoff's theorem on 2^k + p

proven: Romanoff (1934): positive density can be written as 2^k + p
Erdős: positive density of odds CANNOT be written as 2^k + p
Barreto-Leeham (2026): counterexample with Ω ≥ c√(log n/log log n)

insights: Counterexample: infinitely many n where ALL k give large Ω(n-2^k)
Threshold: c·√(log n/log log n) >> log log n for large n
Proof structure: contradiction between threshold bound and conjecture claim
Key insight: √(log n/log log n)/(log log n) = √(log n)/(log log n)^{3/2} → ∞
Related to covering systems used for 2^k + p obstructions
Average Ω(n) ~ log log n (Erdős-Kac flavor)
